byline.contributor: James C. McKinley Jr. contributed reporting.

abstract: New York State Court of Appeals Chief Judge Jonathan Lippman proposes overhaul of grand jury system in light of public outcry over Eric Garner case, in which grand jury declined to indict police officers involved; suggests judges should oversee cases of killings or assaults of civilians by police and be allowed to release information about proceedings to public.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors, who handle the proceedings now, are seen as too close with law enforcement, Jonathan Lippman, the chief judge of the Court of Appeals, said his annual address.

headline.main: Head of New York’s Top Court Says Judges Should Oversee Grand Juries in Deaths Involving Police
headline.print_headline: Revise Grand Jury Rules, Top New York Judge Says
